q001.answer: Rent is due on the 22nd day of each calendar month.

q002.answer: The security deposit amount is S$15,000, which is equivalent to 2 months' rental. If there are no breaches of the agreement by the Tenant, the balance of the security deposit after any deductions for breaches will be refunded without interest within fourteen (14) days from the expiry or termination of the Agreement.

q003.answer: The Tenant is responsible for paying all charges due in respect of any telephone, supply of water, electricity, gas, and any water-borne sewerage system and/or other equipment installed at the Premises, including any tax payable thereon.

q005.answer: The Tenant replaces electric bulbs and tubes at their own expense.

q006.answer: The Tenant would be responsible for paying for repairs if something costs $150 to fix.

q007.answer: The initial $200 of the repair cost will be borne by the Tenant, and any excess beyond $200 will be borne by the Landlord.

q008.answer: The air conditioning should be serviced every three months, and the cost of the service is to be borne by the Landlord.

q009.answer: Alterations to the property are not permitted without the prior written consent of the Landlord. Any alterations, additions, drilling, hacking, or changes of any nature to the Premises must be approved by the Landlord before they can be carried out.

q010.answer: The landlord can enter your apartment for repairs with all necessary appliances at reasonable times by prior appointment mutually agreed upon by both parties for the purpose of viewing the condition of the premises or for carrying out necessary repairs, alterations, or improvements.

q011.answer: Subletting the apartment is allowed with the prior written consent of the Landlord, which should not be unreasonably withheld, especially if the subletter is a respectable or reputable person or corporation.

q012.answer: You are allowed to keep pets in the premises only if you have obtained the prior written permission of the Landlord and comply with any conditions imposed by the Landlord if such permission is granted.

q013.answer: If the rent remains unpaid for 7 days after it is due, the landlord has the right to claim an interest at 10% annually on the unpaid amount. Additionally, if the rent is not paid and there is a default by the tenant, the landlord can re-enter the premises and terminate the tenancy without prejudice to any prior breaches of the tenancy agreement by the tenant.

q014.answer: You can terminate the lease early with a 2 months' notice and forfeiture of the deposit according to the special clause in the agreement.

q015.answer: You are required to inform the Landlord of any visitors staying in the house from time to time. The number of Tenants and occupiers should not exceed the maximum occupants allowed by the authorities.

q016.answer: When moving out, you need to ensure that the premises are delivered back to the landlord in good and tenantable repair and condition, except for fair wear and tear. You should arrange for professional cleaning of the unit, dry clean the curtains, remove any nails, screws, and hooks from the walls, and patch any holes with white putty.

q017.answer: The Tenant is responsible for paying all charges due in respect of any telephone, supply of water, electricity, gas, and any water-borne sewerage system, including any tax payable thereon.

q018.answer: The Tenant is responsible for insurance.

q019.answer: You can hang picture frames on the walls as long as you obtain the written consent of the landlord.

q020.answer: You can renew your lease after it expires if you make a written request to the Landlord at least 2 calendar months before the expiry of the tenancy, provided there have been no breaches or non-observance of any terms and conditions during the term of the tenancy.
